result.markdown:
--- title: "Time Series - Midterm Project" subtitle: "Residential Real Estate Financing Patterns: Insights from Mortgage Averages" author: "By - Sree Lekshmi Prasannan
Jaskirat Singh" format: revealjs #incremental: true editor: source toc: true toc-depth: 1 slide-number: true smaller: false scrollable: true editor_options: chunk_output_type: console output-dir: docs --- # Dataset ## Time Series used in the project - - Real Estate Loans: "Residential Real Estate Loans, All Commercial Banks" from FRED which represents the total amount of residential real estate loans issued by all commercial banks in the United States. - The covariate series used is "30-Year Fixed Rate Mortgage Average" which represents the average interest rate on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages in the United States ## Relevance - - The average interest rate on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages is a crucial factor influencing the affordability of home purchases and the demand for mortgage financing. - By analyzing trends in the fixed-rate mortgage average, we can gain insights into shifts in mortgage interest rates, which in turn can influence housing market activity, including home sales, and overall residential real estate lending. ## Basic statistics about datasets - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-2_ee656d216a8e272ef353af55d6c33b49'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - Both time series are on weekly basis and not seasonally adjusted. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - Total number of rows in real estate loans dataset: 1031 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - Total number of rows in mortgage rate dataset: 2764 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - Summary of real estate loans dataset: ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` date value Min. :2004-06-02 Min. :1396 1st Qu.:2009-05-09 1st Qu.:2036 Median :2014-04-16 Median :2107 Mean :2014-04-16 Mean :2092 3rd Qu.:2019-03-23 3rd Qu.:2226 Max. :2024-02-28 Max. :2574 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - Summary of mortgage rate dataset: ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` date value Min. :1971-04-02 Min. : 2.650 1st Qu.:1984-06-27 1st Qu.: 5.200 Median :1997-09-22 Median : 7.400 Mean :1997-09-22 Mean : 7.733 3rd Qu.:2010-12-17 3rd Qu.: 9.455 Max. :2024-03-14 Max. :18.630 ``` ::: ::: # Data Preparation ## Making start and end dates compatible - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-3_3e51ddeb1b68cec31542ccba7ee07d72'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Start date of real estate loans series: 2004-06-02" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Start date of mortgage rate series: 1971-04-02" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "End date of real estate loans series: 2024-02-28" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "End date of mortgage rate series: 2024-03-14" ``` ::: :::

::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-4_24d41a8bd70b1afec6582db76cdb443e'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Start and end date of both the series after filtering the datasets - ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Start date of real estate loans series: 2004-06-02" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Start date of mortgage rate series: 2004-06-02" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "End date of real estate loans series: 2024-02-28" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "End date of mortgage rate series: 2024-02-28" ``` ::: ::: ## Number of observations after filteration - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-5_bcbdff9e78653503c1249d08cb52bcec'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - Total number of rows in real estate loans: 1031 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - Total number of rows in mortgage rate: 1031 ``` ::: ::: # Data Analysis ## Visualizing the datasets - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-6_f1bebbadedc2110cacf764330f4559ab'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](project_1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](project_1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-6-2.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Correlation coefficient - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-7_943b043407bc36c19a01a801bb27bdb9'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Correlation between Real Estate Loans and Mortgage rate series: -0.2463609 ``` ::: ::: ## ACF and PACF of Real Estate loans - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-8_1872cfe223798c5da59cb63799be05e2'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](project_1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](project_1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-8-2.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## ACF and PACF of Mortgage Rate - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-9_7eca4b95ecf2dc8b55e4a106e84f96a4'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](project_1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](project_1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-9-2.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Decomposition for Real Estate Loans - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-10_507924db390e5221a494e94ddcdb347b'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](project_1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Decomposition for Mortgage rate - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-11_d8db7ceba3b5e72d6018a160ea1eac99'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](project_1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Plotting both the series - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-12_4ee2c917603898e5651b11deab2b0af5'} ```{.r .cell-code} min_max_scale <- function(x) { (x - min(x)) / (max(x) - min(x)) } # Scale the data for each series real_estate_scaled <- filtered_real_estate_loans real_estate_scaled$value <- min_max_scale(filtered_real_estate_loans$value) mortgage_scaled <- filtered_mortgae_rate mortgage_scaled$value <- min_max_scale(filtered_mortgae_rate$value) # Merge data merged_data <- merge(real_estate_scaled, mortgage_scaled, by = "date", all = TRUE) # Plot series ggplot(merged_data, aes(x = date)) + geom_line(aes(y = value.x, color = "Real Estate Loans")) + geom_line(aes(y = value.y, color = "Mortgage Rate")) + labs(title = "Weekly Series: Initial Jobless Claims vs Retail Sales", x = "Date", y = "Value") + scale_color_manual(name = "Series", values = c("Real Estate Loans" = "blue", "Mortgage Rate" = "red")) + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](project_1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Checking for stationarity - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-13_8adace05eaf35993cf860792111e6e2d'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Checking stationarity for Real Estate Loans: ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` ADF Test: Augmented Dickey-Fuller Test data: data Dickey-Fuller = -2.8159, Lag order = 10, p-value = 0.2329 alternative hypothesis: stationary KPSS Test: KPSS Test for Level Stationarity data: data KPSS Level = 9.2076, Truncation lag parameter = 7, p-value = 0.01 ``` ::: :::

::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-14_35fb4b462212c902c92d5c8a8760e19a'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Checking stationarity for Mortgage Rate: ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` ADF Test: Augmented Dickey-Fuller Test data: data Dickey-Fuller = -0.51444, Lag order = 10, p-value = 0.9812 alternative hypothesis: stationary KPSS Test: KPSS Test for Level Stationarity data: data KPSS Level = 3.7472, Truncation lag parameter = 7, p-value = 0.01 ``` ::: ::: ## Making data stationary: ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-15_84157d6dbada8e28b13f78213ebb0ee7'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](project_1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: # Modeling ## Overview - regARIMA model - To model the complex relationship between residential real estate loans and mortgage rates, we employ a Regression with ARIMA errors (RegARIMA) model. - This approach allows for incorporating the average mortgage rate as an external regressor to predict the volume of real estate loans while accounting for auto-correlated residuals and non-stationarity inherent in time series data. ## Mathematical framework The RegARIMA model integrates regression analysis with ARIMA modeling, specified as: $$ y_t = \mathbf{X}_t \boldsymbol{\beta} + n_t $$ where (y_t) is the observed time series at time (t), (\mathbf{X}\_t) represents external regressors, (\boldsymbol{\beta}) denotes the regression coefficients, and (n_t) is an error term following an ARIMA model: $$ \Phi(B) \Delta^d n_t = \Theta(B) \epsilon_t $$ Here, (\Delta\^d) is the differencing operator, (B) the backshift operator, (\Phi(B)) and (\Theta(B)) the AR and MA polynomial operators, and (\epsilon\_t) white noise. ## Application in project - The goal is to analyze how the 30-Year Fixed Rate Mortgage Average impacts the volume of residential real estate loans. - To uncover the relationship between the volume of real estate loans and the average mortgage rate while accounting for autocorrelations within the residuals, we apply a RegARIMA modeling approach. - This section outlines the process from fitting a linear model to adjusting for ARIMA errors. ## Summary of reg ARIMA model - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-16_dc1a6ca506362e88e73e1cf9b697605d'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Series: filtered_real_estate_loans$value Regression with ARIMA(5,1,1) errors Coefficients: ar1 ar2 ar3 ar4 ar5 ma1 drift xreg -0.2217 -0.2829 -0.1260 0.2241 0.2442 0.1891 1.1346 4.7569 s.e. 0.0886 0.0303 0.0414 0.0322 0.0350 0.0877 0.3679 3.4120 sigma^2 = 134.5: log likelihood = -3982.13 AIC=7982.26 AICc=7982.44 BIC=8026.7 Training set error measures: ME RMSE MAE MPE MAPE MASE Training set 0.004017053 11.54541 6.87518 0.002596298 0.336745 0.7590711 ACF1 Training set 0.009363033 ``` ::: ::: ## Summary of reg ARIMA model - ::: {.cell hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-17_5ecc74ec70c915931662803b80f8ffed'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - MAE is 6.88, which tells us the average absolute difference between the observed and predicted values. Lower MAE indicates better prediiction accuracy. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - MPE is positive, which tells us that the model is overestimating the predicted value than the actual value. ``` ::: ::: ## Model equation - ::: {.cell hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-18_469434f6377d9bdbbaae161fd14d087d'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Based on the provided coefficients, the regression ARIMA equation would be: ``` ::: ::: $$ y_t = 1.1346 - 0.2217 \cdot y_{t-1} - 0.2829 \cdot y_{t-2} - 0.1260 \cdot y_{t-3} + 0.2241 \cdot y_{t-4} + 0.2442 \cdot y_{t-5} + 0.1892 \cdot e_{t-1} + 4.7569 \cdot covariate + e_t $$ ## Model Diagnosis - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-19_c0323ef3076ceba4eb2ea584b45595ae'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](project_1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Ljung-Box test data: Residuals from Regression with ARIMA(5,1,1) errors Q* = 37.698, df = 4, p-value = 1.293e-07 Model df: 6. Total lags used: 10 ``` ::: ::: ## Model Diagnosis - ::: {.cell hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-20_fa6c276a149f550f6a4ef0ddb3d12f69'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Residuals over time: ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - Residuals fluctuate around the zero line, which is expected. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - There are several spikes that stand out, suggesting potential outliers or model misspecification. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - The variance of residuals appears constant over time, indicating no obvious signs of heteroscedasticity. ``` ::: :::

::: {.cell hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-21_e7bd416eb32b16d2080c988a80507662'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Autocorrelation Function (ACF) of Residuals: ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - The ACF plot does not show significant autocorrelations for any lag, as most of the bars are within the blue dashed confidence interval lines. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - This indicates that the residuals do not exhibit autocorrelation and the model is capturing the data's temporal structure well. ``` ::: :::

::: {.cell hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-22_0b3963ea181dbdf7831214ecbfe9ffa4'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Histogram and Density of Residuals: ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - The histogram shows the distribution of residuals with a superimposed red line representing the normal distribution. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - Residuals are approximately normally distributed but show a slight leftward skew, suggesting a minor deviation from normality. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - Despite the skew, the distribution of residuals does not show extreme deviations from the expected normal distribution. ``` ::: ::: ## Overview - VAR (Vector Autoregression) model - The Vector Autoregression (VAR) model is a type of time series model used for forecasting multiple time series variables simultaneously. - It extends the univariate autoregressive model to handle multiple time series variables that may interact with each other over time. ## Mathematical framework - - VAR models are based on the assumption that each variable in the system is linearly dependent on its own lagged values as well as the lagged values of all other variables in the system. - Mathematically, a VAR(p) model of order p for k time series variables can be represented as: Where: Yt is a k-dimensional vector of endogenous variables at time t. C is a k-dimensional vector representing the intercept term. Φ1, Φ2, ..., Φp are coefficient matrices of lagged values up to order p. Ut is a k-dimensional vector of error terms at time t. ## Summary of VAR model - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-23_c4a43d3d5fbd683d95d7b05ab122117f'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Summary of VAR model - ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` VAR Estimation Results: ========================= Endogenous variables: value.x, value.y Deterministic variables: const Sample size: 1001 Log Likelihood: -3132.938 Roots of the characteristic polynomial: 1.001 0.9943 Call: VAR(y = ts_combined_data[, c("value.x", "value.y")]) Estimation results for equation value.x: ======================================== value.x = value.x.l1 + value.y.l1 + const Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) value.x.l1 0.996863 0.001887 528.195 <2e-16 *** value.y.l1 0.643731 0.374338 1.720 0.0858 . const 4.695354 4.734422 0.992 0.3216 --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Residual standard error: 13.68 on 998 degrees of freedom Multiple R-Squared: 0.9967, Adjusted R-squared: 0.9966 F-statistic: 1.486e+05 on 2 and 998 DF, p-value: < 2.2e-16 Estimation results for equation value.y: ======================================== value.y = value.x.l1 + value.y.l1 + const Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) value.x.l1 1.565e-05 1.354e-05 1.156 0.248 value.y.l1 9.983e-01 2.686e-03 371.692 <2e-16 *** const -2.391e-02 3.397e-02 -0.704 0.482 --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Residual standard error: 0.09816 on 998 degrees of freedom Multiple R-Squared: 0.9933, Adjusted R-squared: 0.9933 F-statistic: 7.359e+04 on 2 and 998 DF, p-value: < 2.2e-16 Covariance matrix of residuals: value.x value.y value.x 187.19559 0.008190 value.y 0.00819 0.009636 Correlation matrix of residuals: value.x value.y value.x 1.000000 0.006098 value.y 0.006098 1.000000 ``` ::: ::: ## Model diagnostics: ::: {.cell hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-24_ce1f6526959531f93f143fe39120cc11'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Root of the Characteristic Polynomial: ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - The roots of the characteristic polynomial are provided. These roots are essential for understanding the stability of the model. In this case, the roots are 1.001 and 0.9943, indicating that the model is stable. ``` ::: :::

::: {.cell hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-25_e3f29545ecf3be54d0c65f685dfa1449'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Residual Analysis: ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - Covariance matrix provides the covariance between residuals of each equation. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - t helps in understanding the linear relationship between the residuals of different equations. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - The RSE of 13.68 for house loans series means that, on average, the observed values of the endogenous variables deviate from the values predicted by the VAR model by approximately 13.68 units. ``` ::: ::: # Forecasting ## regARIMA model - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-26_4190eb25c8f2b78152ecc4e094f3b4c6'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](project_1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-26-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Forecasted value for the next week: 2574.019 ``` ::: ::: ## Cross-Validation - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-27_e3c3d2f16c16c12f01e24e5f11aeaf51'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - RMSE value after cross validatiion: 13.87549 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - MAE value after cross validatiion: 8.950738 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - MAPE value after cross validatiion: 0.008412029 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Forecasted value for the next week: 2293.682 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Forecasted value for regARIMA without cross validation has less error rate and thus final forecasted value for regARIMA model is: 2574.019 ``` ::: ::: ## VAR model - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-28_9cb238581799115ac10ed0317e4a90bf'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](project_1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-28-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-29_e6273ca86d06ef52229bcd3c47f01c3b'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Forecasted value for the next week: 2573.884 ``` ::: ::: ## Cross-Validation - ::: {.cell output-location='slide' hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-30_ed76536a34c64fc4955824dc06647adc'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` RMSE value for VAR model using cross validation: 907.7228 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` MAE value for VAR model using cross validation: 683.9339 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` MAPE value for VAR model using cross validation: 33.13922 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Forecasted value for the next week using cross validation: 2093.624 ``` ::: ::: # Comparison ## Error rates and forecasted values - ::: {.cell hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-31_70886753b601aed34060426e6a7b7368'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` MAE value for regARIMA without cross-validation: 6.87518 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` MAE value for regARIMA with cross-validation: 8.950738 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` MAE for VAR without cross-validation: 13.68 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` MAE for VAR with cross-validation: 686.3736 ``` ::: :::

::: {.cell hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-32_78e81db493be7275f4182ae4b0d6c694'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Forecasted value for regARIMA without cross-validation: 2574.019 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Forecasted value for regARIMA with cross-validation: 2293.682 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Forecasted for VAR without cross-validation: 2573.884 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Forecasted for VAR with cross-validation: 2110.842 ``` ::: ::: # Conclusion ## Final forecasted value Final forecasted value is chosen from regARIMA model without cross-validation: 2574.019 ## Practical Applications ::: {.cell hash='project_1_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-33_c2ddb3ba6cf4bb1c466d79a7d23010ea'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - Lending Strategies: Banks can adjust their lending strategies based on predicted mortgage rate trends, optimizing interest rates to balance profit with risk. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - Risk Management: Predictions of loan volumes can inform risk assessments and capital reserve requirements to maintain financial stability. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - Market Analysis: Developers and real estate agencies can use these forecasts to anticipate market demand, informing decisions about when to build, sell, or market properties. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` - Pricing Strategy: Accurate predictions of loans and interest rates can help set appropriate property pricing strategies to match market conditions. ``` ::: :::

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
